EBC NO2 − and Inflammation Correlation coefficients and p values for the relations between EBC NO2 − and pulmonary or systemic markers of inflammation are depicted in Table 3 . No significant correlation between the chosen markers of inflammation and EBC NO2 − were observed. A correlation of EBC NO2 − with pulmonary or systemic inflammation is therefore not supported by our results. EBC NO2 − Normalized to Vt If EBC NO2 − truly reflects pulmonary distension, and if distension is greater in more severe lung injury due to derecruitment, the relation of EBC NO2 − and Vt (ie, EBC NO2 −/Vt [milliliters per kilogram of BW] ratio) should be directly correlated to the extent of lung injury. In support of this assumption, Figure 3 indeed demonstrates significant correlations of the continuous-parameter LISS with EBC NO2 −/Vt ratio (Fig 3, right; r = 0.84, p < 0.0001) as well as of the Pao 2/fraction of inspired oxygen (Fio 2) ratio (the continuous parameter of the AECC classification) with EBC NO2 −/Vt (Fig 3, left; r = 0.66, p < 0.0001). In contrast, no correlation of Vt alone with either LISS or Pao 2/Fio 2 was observed (LISS, r = 0.05, p = 0.77; Pao 2/Fio 2, r = 0.17, p = 0.32).

The study found no significant correlation between EBC NO2 − and pulmonary or systemic markers of inflammation, suggesting that nitrite levels do not reflect inflammatory processes in the studied conditions. Although there are correlations with lung injury parameters, the lack of a direct relationship with inflammation indicates a complex interaction that does not support a straightforward link between nitrite and inflammation.
